title: Daniel in the Lions' Den
shortSummary: Daniel 6 recounts the story of Daniel's unwavering faithfulness to God despite a royal decree forbidding prayer to anyone but King Darius. His steadfast obedience leads to his miraculous deliverance from the lions' den, demonstrating God's power and faithfulness to those who trust Him.
timeline: c. 539 BC - Early Persian Empire under King Darius

keyCharacters.name: Daniel
keyCharacters.description: A faithful Jewish exile and high-ranking official in King Darius's kingdom who continues to pray to God despite a royal edict forbidding it.

keyCharacters.name: King Darius
keyCharacters.description: The Persian king who sets the decree that leads to Daniel's trial but ultimately honors Daniel’s God after witnessing His deliverance.

keyCharacters.name: Princes and Presidents
keyCharacters.description: Jealous officials who conspire against Daniel by manipulating the king to issue a decree that targets Daniel's prayer life.

definitions.term: Law of the Medes and Persians
definitions.definition: An unchangeable royal decree in the Persian Empire that could not be revoked once signed by the king.
A pit where lions were kept; used as a place of execution by exposing condemned persons to lions.
A formal request or prayer made to God or a ruler.
A seal used to authenticate documents, symbolizing the king’s authority and the irrevocability of the decree.

outline.heading: Daniel's Promotion and Jealousy of Officials
outline.description: King Darius appoints Daniel over the kingdom, provoking jealousy among other officials who fail to find any fault in him except regarding his loyalty to God.

outline.heading: The Decree Against Prayer
outline.description: The conspirators convince King Darius to sign a decree forbidding prayer to anyone but the king for thirty days, under penalty of being thrown into the lions’ den.

outline.heading: Daniel’s Faithfulness and Arrest
outline.description: Daniel continues to pray openly to God despite the decree, leading to his arrest and being cast into the lions’ den, while the king struggles to find a way to save him.

outline.heading: God’s Deliverance of Daniel
outline.description: King Darius anxiously waits and then joyfully finds Daniel unharmed, as God miraculously shuts the lions’ mouths, vindicating Daniel’s innocence.

outline.heading: Judgment on the Accusers and Royal Proclamation
outline.description: The conspirators and their families are punished by the lions, and King Darius issues a decree honoring the God of Daniel as the living and eternal God.

application: Remain steadfast in prayer and obedience to God even when facing opposition or persecution.
Trust in God's sovereign power to protect and deliver His faithful servants in times of trial.
Recognize the importance of integrity and faithfulness in all areas of life, as Daniel exemplified.
Honor God publicly through consistent worship and thanksgiving, regardless of cultural or political pressures.

keyVerses.text: Now when Daniel knew that the writing was signed, he went into his house; and his windows being open in his chamber toward Jerusalem, he kneeled upon his knees three times a day, and prayed, and gave thanks before his God, as he did aforetime.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Daniel’s unwavering commitment to prayer and worship despite the threat of death.

keyVerses.text: My God hath sent his angel, and hath shut the lions' mouths, that they have not hurt me: forasmuch as before him innocency was found in me; and also before thee, O king, have I done no hurt.
keyVerses.significance: Daniel credits God’s intervention for his deliverance, affirming God’s justice and protection for the innocent.

keyVerses.text: I make a decree, That in every dominion of my kingdom men tremble and fear before the God of Daniel: for he is the living God, and stedfast for ever, and his kingdom that which shall not be destroyed, and his dominion shall be even unto the end.
keyVerses.significance: King Darius publicly acknowledges the sovereignty and eternal nature of God, underscoring the chapter’s message of God’s supremacy.
